content.intro:
Appealing, wild, twirling and proud, Catania is one of those cities that take you to another world. Get ready for history, baroque magnificence and amazing cultural riches.

Inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 2002, the city is nestled on the eastern shore of Sicily, like a crown delicately laid on the Etna's lava.
As the origin of the world suggests - Katane in Sicilian meaning "harsh place", "rugged and rough soil" - Catania is not easily tamed. You have to agree to lose yourself in its midst to win its charms. In turn enchanting and impetuous, the city perfectly embodies the ideals of Late Baroque periods. Like a pearl of uneven nature, it breaks free from classical rules. Architecture, sculpture, painting, music and literature make for an unlimited art trove in a very Latin sort of disorder. It was the birthplace of composer Vincenzo Bellini and author Giovanni Verga. It was a home of princes, suffered Arab and Norman invasions, and now radiates stirring magnetism in each and every street, monument and market place.
Destroyed and rebuilt seven times over the centuries, this old port town bears the elephant as an emblem, celebrated with a fountain on the Piazza del Duomo. The animal embodies the successive influences that gave the city its identity, an island halfway between east and west shaped by Aeolus' winds and the Mediterranean Sea.
Catania, like the remainder of the territory, celebrates the island's everlasting beauties, which Giuseppe Tomasi di Lampedusa - author of The Leopard, adapted for the screen by Visconti - paid tribute to in his novella The Professor and the Siren: "So we spoke about eternal Sicily, the Sicily of the natural world; about the scent of rosemary on the Nebrodi Mountains and the taste of Melilli honey; about the swaying cornfields seen from Etna on a windy day in May". Buon viaggio!

content.title: Santuzza Hotel, when traditions and Contemporary Art meet

introduction.small: In the heart of Catania's historic centre and facing the Villa Bellini, the Santuzza Boutique Hotel reveals a location that oozes art… yet remains totally family friendly.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Santuzza Hotel, when traditions and Contemporary Art meet

paragraphs.text:
The Contemporary Art paintings displayed at the front desk and in the bedrooms provide a stark contrast with Santuzza Hotel's historic facade. A stone's throw from the Piazza del Duomo, in the heart of Catania, its 18 arty rooms take up the last two floors of the building, renovated in a very stylish manner. Some even offer a unique view over the Bellini Gardens right across the hotel, as well as the Etna, Sicily's emblematic volcano.

Considering the boutique hotel's ideal location, its leitmotif calls for “vivere la città” (“live the city”, in Italian). It is indeed quite easy to walk around, from museums to cathedrals, gardens to monuments. As they come back to the hotel, families are delighted to find a playground in its midst, dedicated to young guests. A baby-sitting service is also provided for parents to enjoy, for one evening, a very special one-to-one moment. True happiness, Italian style!

Rooms: from 47 EUR

content.title: Exclusive 4-day gourmet food and wine tour in Sicily

introduction.small: Journey through the island of the Ancients dubbed ‘God's kitchen' uncovering its rich food and wine heritage.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Exclusive 4-day gourmet food and wine tour in Sicily

paragraphs.text:
Start your wine and food odyssey exploring Palermo, Sicily's capital, known for its layers of history, imposing architecture and Mediterranean hustle and bustle.

Head south to discover the island's Greek heritage and marvel at its magnificently preserved Valley of the Temples near Agrigento backed by an azure blue sky and the sound of the cicadas.

Hone your culinary skills and learn how to prepare delicious traditional dishes intertwining Greek, Arabic and Norman traditions with modern Sicilian style.

After a long day cooking, you will be ready to relax at an intimate boutique hotel surrounded with majestic cork plantations and rolling vineyards. Indulge your senses with authentic local produce accompanied by the estate's award-winning wines while tasting local varieties such as Nero d'Avola, Frappato or refreshing your palate with a crisp Grillo.

Go on a wine safari at Feudi del Pisciotto and spend the afternoon pampering your body and soul at the on-site spa.

Complete your trip with a visit to an ancient baroque estate surrounded by olive and almond trees and learn about albarello, how the soil and climate influence production. Enjoy a final lunch at an eco-friendly resort.

Excessive drinking may cause health problems. Drink in moderation.

content.title: Banacher, Catania's prestigious night club

introduction.small: The idyllic setting and seafront view have turned it into the jewel of Sicilian nightclubs… and much more!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Banacher, Catania's prestigious night club

paragraphs.text:
As night falls, head over to Aci Castello, about a dozen miles from Catania, as you would venture into another world. For it is in this small town facing the Cyclopean Islands marine reserve that you will find the Banacher, the major outdoor Sicilian nightclub. Here, amid luxurious vegetation, everybody gathers to party! The exotic climate that reigns in this historical club turns it into a musical oasis at the heart of the Sicilian city. Take advantage and enjoy dinner at its restaurant or sip on a cocktail by the pool. Both are ideal to take in the incredibly festive atmosphere. The three dancefloors will take care of the rest from Tuesday to Sunday, putting on an explosive show until the sun comes up. The various themes, DJ setlists and exceptional setting will undoubtedly satisfy all tastes and desires. A recipe for success!

content.title: Osteria Antica Marina, the catch of the day

introduction.small: It would be a sin not to taste the many treasures from the Ionian Sea, at the heart of the Pescheria, where the fish market is a must-see.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Osteria Antica Marina, the catch of the day

paragraphs.text:
Make the most of your visit in the island's famous fish market by strolling down its paths and try the miraculous catch offered there.
Situated right in the middle of this vibrant and lively place, the Osteria Antica Marina restaurant gives you a prime location for watching the merchants come and go, with stalls full of shellfish taken out of their baskets… It will be impossible to resist the call of the mermaid, or rather the cry of the chef presenting his menu: marinated shrimp, swordfish tartare, linguine with tuna eggs, sautéed mussels and clams... Expect even more freshness for dessert, savouring a bowl of strawberries with whipped cream or a delicious lemon sorbet.
The colours, the mood, the folklore of this place are such a delight that is has become a very attractive address; so do not forget to book in advance…

content.title: Cultural break in Acireale

introduction.small: The natural surroundings of this small spa resort are brimming with surprises that will perfect your Sicilian stay.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cultural break in Acireale

paragraphs.text:
The small Baroque town of Acireala is located only a few kilometres north of Catania and it offers breathtaking views of the Ionian Sea. During your trip, take the time to absorb the art and culture that permeate the air, while still enjoying the charming countryside vistas that spread as far as the eye can see.
The city centre is filled with monuments, a splendid cathedral that dates back to the 15th century, the unmissable Basilica dei Santi Apostoli Pietro e Paolo, the Town Hall, as well as the equally famous Palazzo Modò.
For nature lovers, an exploration of the “Timpa” will reveal a reserve brimming with lava rocks and thick vegetation near the shore. Acireale is also well known for an extravagant carnival that has taken place every February since the 16th century. It still remains one of the most spectacular shows in Sicily. Grandiose flower-covered floats parade in the streets for everyone's enjoyment.

content.title: Catania's markets, an olfactory journey

introduction.small: As real slices of life, Catania's markets offer a quaint and tumultuous show. This is an original and gourmet way of discovering the city's traditions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Catania's markets, an olfactory journey

paragraphs.text:
Going to the market each morning is for many locals an unshakable habit. Streets and squares buzz with activity until midday. From 6 a.m. onwards on the Piazza del Duomo, La Pescheria's fishmongers set up the fish stalls with fresh catches, as customers chat about yesterday's football game, coffee in hand. Fish stalls rub shoulders with cheese and produce, laid in wooden crates directly on the ground. Over there, some swordfish, over here mountains of lemons and purple cauliflowers. Not to mention various rigatti (escargots).
For a jumble-type of market, the Via Pacini one spreads all the way to Corso Italia. There, you will find clothes, sunglasses, spices and various foods. Carry on towards Piazza Giovanni Verga for the Campagna Amica organic market, ideal to bring cold cuts, honey and produce of unrivalled taste back home.
Finally head for the Carlo Alberto square to admire the famous Fera 'o Luni market, a major shopping spot where fresh products, clothes and spices challenge your eyes with bright popping colours on every stall.

content.title: ZO, the avant-garde of contemporary culture

introduction.small: A former sulphate factory turned into Contemporary Art centre: in Catania, the past is not all that matters!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: ZO, the avant-garde of contemporary culture

paragraphs.text:
Distribution, support, promotion… ZO has shaped up to be the place of cultural expression and production in Sicily. In the Green Room (the amphitheatre) or the Grey Room (which displays a cosier atmosphere), the concerts, shows, exhibitions, conferences and performances keep coming.
As a stronghold of multidisciplinary creation, this 1,600 square-meter space has shown to be quite proactive. With the support of Catania's city hall, it has created artists-in-residence programs that attract crowds, as students come and meet professionals while others partake in multimedia workshops. Lured in by the rich bimonthly program, visitors gather regularly for festivals, plays or even just to visit the bookshop. If you care to take a break at the cafeteria (located in the former sulphate production unit site), you can still make out the original bricks used for its construction, as they have been discovered during renovation work. ZO's energy is catchy. Experience it too!

content.title: Taormina the beautiful

introduction.small: About 50 kilometres from Catania, Taormina offers striking vistas and delights of history.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Taormina the beautiful

paragraphs.text:
A small town perched on the cliffs overlooking the deep blue Ionian Sea, Taormina oozes luxury and serenity. Walk around the streets, enjoy the views of the Etna and even, when the skies are clear, of Calabria! Founded by the Greek a few kilometres off its actual location, the city was ruled the Kingdom of Syracuse before Romans took over, as for the whole of Sicily.
The paved streets will lead you to the ancient theatre and its exceptional sound system, incredibly preserved and still standing after 23 centuries. Taormina's charm is to be found in the medieval town and its gorgeous palaces, like the Palazzo Corvaja and the Palazzo dei Duchi di Santo Stefano. Without the shadow of a doubt, the 12th century cathedral and San Caterina Baroque church will also dazzle you. A stone's throw away, the aptly named Isola Bella beach is calling your name. Just give in!

content.title: Pleasure and simplicity at Trattoria U Fucularu

introduction.small: Relish a refined cuisine in this typical trattoria and fulfil your every need of Mediterranean flavours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pleasure and simplicity at Trattoria U Fucularu

paragraphs.text:
A convivial atmosphere reigns in this family inn located at the heart of Catania's historic centre. Featuring exposed stone walls, the rustic style of the decoration is nothing short of refined. As an appetizer, succumb to the famous buffet of antipasti - delicacies prepared with meat, fish or vegetables you savour before the main course. The delicious mozzarella, supplied directly from a local producer, deserves a special mention!
Next, indulge in the remarkable grilled food of this region - such as breaded horse filet, veal steak or pork chops - paired with an excellent local wine, and for a very reasonable price. You may want to end on a sweet note by having a lemon sorbet or a white chocolate fondant. All of these specialities are to be tried in the small, yet pleasant terrace situated next to the must-see duomo. Become a true Sicilian over lunch!

content.title: Cultural getaway in Palermo

introduction.small: Come and grasp what the charismatic city of Palermo is all about, a few hundred kilometres away from Catania.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cultural getaway in Palermo

paragraphs.text:
The city of Palermo is filled with complex history, going back to the Antiquity. Its strategic position in the heart of the Mediterranean caused it several invasions, by Normand, Greek and Spanish Bourbons. The results of this past are many and varied: sumptuous palaces rub shoulders with monuments in ruins, and sunny beaches contrast with shady streets.
During your trip in the largest Sicilian city, take some time to admire the Capo market. You will come across the best dry fruits, flavoured olives, dried tomatoes and other local specialities.
Make sure you stop by the Santa Maria Assunta Cathedral, a gigantic medieval monument built in the 12th century. Another major location is the Cappuccini catacombs, where 8,000 mummified corpses will welcome you in their underground passages shaped directly in the lava rock. One thing is certain, no one remains indifferent to Palermo's unexpected surprises!

content.title: Castello Ursino, the castle that does not crack up

introduction.small: Stern and mysterious, it hides a blazing history, jealously guarded behind those foreboding towers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Castello Ursino, the castle that does not crack up

paragraphs.text:
To each castle its legend. Ursino is therefore considered as an unassailable fortress. Built in the 13th century, the impressive construct and its four towers were ordered by Frederick II, King of Sicily. Constantly at war with the papacy, this tempestuous sovereign, dearly loved by his people, provoked the wrath of Pope Gregory IX, who compared him to the Antichrist. His followers bestowed the Sleeping Emperor moniker on him, due to his aura and scandalous reputation, for they believed he would come back to them after a long sleep in the volcano's crater.
Good or evil, the building is one of the few to have withstood the 1693 earthquake. It was even said that its pit filled up with lava when the Etna blew up with anger in the 17th century. Calmer today, the castle houses a museum that offers temporary exhibitions. Let the castello's history carry you away, as you are reminded of its grandiose magnificence.

content.title: Explore every inch of the Cyclopean Isles

introduction.small: Close to Catania, the Cyclopean Isles will surprise scuba diving enthusiasts with an exceptional seabed.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Explore every inch of the Cyclopean Isles

paragraphs.text:
The town of Acci Trezza is located on the east coast of Sicily. It shelters strange rock formations nicknamed Faraglioni di Trezza by the locals, but more commonly known as the "Cyclopean Isles". Make a stop to examine the surprising shapes the rock took with years due to the rise of the seabed, as well as the Etna's lava flow.
Encompassing 623 hectares, the Cyclopean archipelago is also a natural site of interest for anyone who loves to scuba dive. Fauna and flora are composed of incredible seaweed and fish species in this part the Mediterranean, albeit only a few metres deep down. You'll therefore be able to gaze at sponge colonies, red starfishes, pikes, rays and lobsters. The water is incredibly clear, allowing this natural reserve be discovered on board a glass-bottom boat. Whichever option you choose, you'll be as close to this aquatic life as possible.

content.title: Palazzo Cerami: the charm and refinement of Catania

introduction.small: A dreamlike location for a princely night in a Sicilian palace.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Palazzo Cerami: the charm and refinement of Catania

paragraphs.text:
Just like in Venice, Catania's palaces from the historic centre hide treasures of incredible beauty within their patinated walls. Pushing the heavy door of a façade marked by time, you will be sent into another universe… Here, climbing up to the first floor, you will discover the Palazzo Cerami bed and breakfast – a very bright place full of subtle delicateness. Your host, the lovely Clara, will welcome you with care in the family palace.
Let the princely look of the four bedrooms lure you in. High ceilings, soft, soothing colour palettes, luxurious padded headboards and long taffeta curtains, blazing under the Sicilian sunlight which fills the entire room through large windows... The delight goes on with a generous breakfast served at Clara's that includes freshly squeezed orange juice… You know the saying: the devil is in the detail!

content.title: Romano House, contemporary Baroque

introduction.small: For business and leisure trips alike, Romano Palace's little brother offers another prime location in a lively neighbourhood, right next to the old town.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Romano House, contemporary Baroque

paragraphs.text:
The Romano House celebrates the harmonious union of Baroque and 17th-century architecture with contemporary design. Elegant, sophisticated rooms and suites - richly adorned with ceiling frescoes, elaborate lightning and refined fabrics - aim to be the perfect backdrop of your Sicilian nights. Ideally located in the immediate vicinity of the old town and the business district, the Romano House hotel proves to be a luxurious choice at a reasonable price.
The minimalist setting of its restaurant Il Riccio, dressed in black and white with hints of red, gives pride of place to Sicilian gastronomy by favouring local products. Night birds will also appreciate the perfect location of the premises: nightlife is in full swing just a few streets away. On the other hand, if you would rather opt for a bit of rest, pick a bedroom that overlooks the inner courtyard.
Note: your stay at the Romano House hotel grants you access to the gorgeous outdoor swimming pool of the five-star Romano Palace. Feel free to try it!

content.title: Up the Etna, giant among volcanos

introduction.small: Be it on foot, a four-wheeler, a horse or, why not, on board a helicopter, conquer the tallest European volcano and its 2,352 metres!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Up the Etna, giant among volcanos

paragraphs.text:
Glowing lava flow over the slopes of the sacred volcanic monster: here's the incredible spectacle that struck Sicily in 2017. Rest assured: when the Etna goes back to sleep, it kindly welcomes you up to the top.
The road zigzags through small villages, piano piano (gently) up to the car park, the starting point of your trek. You could alternately just use a cable-car that takes you 2,500 metres high to the first access level of the volcano. If you keep on climbing, you will reach 2,900 metres. The dark soil, wind and high altitude almost make you believe you are walking on the moon. A total change of scenery! Visits of the dizzyingly high main crater and thousand-year-old caves on the second level can only be accessed under the strict guidance and supervision of an authorized guide, depending on current weather conditions. In any case, cover up: Aeolus is blowing hard!

content.title: Casa d'Aria and the colours of Sicilian life

introduction.small: Far from the luxury of palaces, a wonderful way to immerse yourself in the authenticity of the island.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Casa d'Aria and the colours of Sicilian life

paragraphs.text:
Vibrant tones shine all around you: deep blue, golden yellow, ochre and sienna. Located by the Massimo Bellini theatre, every apartment of Casa d'Aria indeed has its own unique world, decor and colour - but they all share the same taste, warmth, character and authenticity to be found in Sicilian houses.
If, with regard to your past experiences, the codes of the hotel trade sometimes feel cold and impersonal, at Casa d'Aria though, you will feel right at home. A kind team will meet your every need and share expert advice to prepare your escapade in and out of the city: generous and attentive, they will even suggest outings or customised activities. If you did not have time to draw up a tourist profile before you left, the Casa d'Aria might well become the trump card for your stay. Sounds like real holidays, doesn't it?

content.title: Via Etnea, the untamed

introduction.small: The city's historic street lives night and day to the pace of shops and restaurants. To your heart's content.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Via Etnea, the untamed

paragraphs.text:
This large main street spreads, like the name suggests, from the Piazza del Duomo to the majestic volcano that overlooks the city. If its route has been modified several times over centuries, it has somehow retained its warm and lively character.
Pedestrianised more than ten years ago, it drags crowds from neighbouring districts. Give free rein to your shopping craze and do not miss to use side streets. The main avenue is riddled with charming boutiques, genuine trattorie and all kinds of shops selling local crafts. End the day with a cannolo treat, the key Sicilian dessert, or take a bite of arancini, the delicious stuffed and fried rice balls, served with a glass of local wine. To do so, just step in the famous Pasticceria Spinella or go for one of the various restaurants located along the way if you need a hearty meal: Etnea Roof for instance also offers unobstructed views of the city from its rooftop terrace. Do not hesitate to enter some ancient palazzi, where you will find unexpected green and peaceful oases, away from the lively street.

content.title: B&B Faro, a place dedicated to art

introduction.small: The city is packed with small treasures, amongst which is B&B Faro, an oasis of calm located firmly in the middle of the urban tumult.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: B&B Faro, a place dedicated to art

paragraphs.text:
Right in the city centre of Catania, Anna and Antonio will welcome you in a vast apartment situated at the 3rd floor of a rather austere-looking building. The inside, though, is masterfully decorated by your hosts - he being a contemporary painter, she being a sculptor - a real eye-candy for art lovers. In this house, you will wander about in large rooms filled with elegant paintings and sculptures of dancers.
The bright, spacious rooms also feature works by the same artists, bringing a sense of peace and contemplation which feels like a privileged sanctuary after a day of immersion in the heart of the bustling city. In the morning, a delicious breakfast will be ready for you in the beautiful dining room, as you listen to soft jazz or classical music. Book early; this place has built an excellent reputation. A lovely and rare address where it is good to feel comfortable…

content.title: UNA Hotel Palace, a combination of luxury and modernity

introduction.small: Courtesy of UNA Hotel & Resorts in Sicily, Catania's prestigious UNA Hotel Palace plays the hand of excellence in true Italian style.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: UNA Hotel Palace, a combination of luxury and modernity

paragraphs.text:
At the heart of the historic centre of the city, the UNA Hotel Palace is located in a splendid edifice dating back to the beginning of the last century. The building has been decorated in a contemporary fashion without selling its Sicilian soul. The 80 rooms and 14 suites, all elegantly dressed in white, perfectly celebrate the union of baroque and contemporary styles. The staff cheerfully takes care of everything with concern and gentleness.
On the first floor, the UNA Restaurant overlooks a lava-stone courtyard, thus perpetuating the tradition of the old houses in the city. A second restaurant -aptly named "Etnea Roof" - up on 7th floor - features a spectacular view over the city roofs and Mount Etna.
From 7:30 p.m. to 10:30 p.m., do not miss out on the city's trendiest aperitivo-happy hour on the terrace; later in the night, indulge in a longer break with a cocktail to fully enjoy the magical scenery.

content.title: B&B Sciara Biscari

introduction.small: Leave downtown and savour your breakfast while enjoying the sea breeze from the nearby beach. Welcome to B&B Sciara Biscari!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: B&B Sciara Biscari

paragraphs.text:
Close to Catania's beach of golden sand, this guesthouse - located only ten minutes away by bus from downtown - neighbours the old fishing village formerly known as "Villa Scabrosa". Built upon the lava which buried Catania during the 1669 eruption, the house has recently been renovated from floor to ceiling.
Not a single Baroque palace in sight; only the lighthouse of Biscari stands proudly a few yards away. The modern and refined rooms provide all the necessary comfort. You will wake up to a hearty and delicious breakfast composed of homemade cakes, yogurts and regional scones.
Your receptive and cordial hosts will give you tips for tailor-made excursions. They even manage a shuttle service from and to the airport: a delicate attention - so rare that it deserves mention - as well as a precious indicator of the quality of service offered by this bed & breakfast.

content.title: Monastero dei Benedettini, history and knowledge

introduction.small: Second largest monastery in Europe after Mafra in Portugal, the Monastero dei Benedettini has now been converted into a university. It retains the splendours of its past.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Monastero dei Benedettini, history and knowledge

paragraphs.text:
History put its stamp on every stone of this impressive structure of 100,000 sqm. As it was devastated by the 1693 earthquake, the greatest Italian architects of the time were called upon to help rebuilt the monastery according to the guidelines of Sicilian Baroque's golden age. It became the department of Humanities of the University of Catania in 1977, and the magic and poetry of the place have endured.
Drool over the 270,000 books, manuscripts, parchments, herbariums and rare volumes, all preciously preserved in the five reading rooms – including the beautiful Vaccarini Hall. Walk around the chapel with wonder, use the monumental grand staircase, cross the refectory, the remains of Roman houses underground, and finally the flowered cloister. Do not miss a guided tour to better grasp what this monastery was like in its glory days.

content.title: Syracuse, land of wonders

introduction.small: Situated in the southeast of Sicily, Syracuse is renowned for its ancient ruins and Baroque architecture. Since 2005, its historical centre has been listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Syracuse, land of wonders

paragraphs.text:
The birthplace of mathematician Archimedes, who lived in 3rd century B.C., is a major spot of any trip to Sicily. Take a few moments to admire the impressive natural spectacle of Syracuse, its impressive and unobstructed views of the Ionian Sea. For a cultural break, visit the numerous Baroque churches of Spanish influence, the Duomo and its Greek look, as well as the various Gothic palazzi. Dozens of food specialities will titillate your taste buds, like the caponata - a regional dish made of eggplant, tomato, celery, vinegar and sugar - or the famous panelle, those little rolls made of chickpea flour.
Do not pass by a shopping session! You will have a large choice of luxury and small designer boutiques, as well as souvenir shops. And finally, you'll find refreshing and relaxing spots with spread out stretches of white sand and untouched coves, in the Vendicari natural reserve. Heaven on earth!

Syracuse
96100 Siracusa

content.title: EH13: an out-of-ordinary bed & breakfast

introduction.small: A boutique hotel with bed & breakfast services, EH13 defies categorisation. Successful bet for this charming place, situated in a perfect location.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: EH13: an out-of-ordinary bed & breakfast

paragraphs.text:
A couple of yards away from the main shopping thoroughfare, EH13 opens its doors at the 4th floor of a modern building. Though the façade might not strike you at first, it actually contrasts with the splendour of a four-room apartment boasting a sleek design.
This bed & breakfast was designed by architect Loredana Cucinotta whose philosophy, focusing on luxury and extreme functionality, confers to these bedroom suites a warm and intimate - albeit unconventional - atmosphere. The collaboration between the architect and the famous Rizzotti brand gives a showroom feel to the different spaces as you can purchase some pieces of decor. Clever, right? EH13 also offers shuttle and car rental services.
However, the essential centrepiece of this place is nothing else than your host, Salvatore. Open and responsive, he will welcome you with unparalleled kindness.

EH13
Via Sant'Euplio, 13
95124 Catania

+39 095 715 2216

www.eh13.it

Rooms: from 80 EUR

content.title: Piazza del Duomo and the mystery of the Elephant Fountain

introduction.small: Nicknamed the “City of the Elephant” during Arab rule, Catania shelters a fountain in its midst, where an impressive black basalt pachyderm stands.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Piazza del Duomo and the mystery of the Elephant Fountain

paragraphs.text:
U liotru, Catania's emblem as it is called in local dialect, watches over the city. It is not known when exactly the 3.61 metres-high massive statue was built, but it bears an Egyptian obelisk on its back, itself mounted with the Saint Agathe symbol. This strange mix is the basis of the unmissable Fontana dell'Elefante, built between 1735 and 1737 by architect Giovanni Battista Vaccarini.
The pachyderm's origins remain a mystery, but an old legend tells the story of an elephant hunting wild animals as Katane was being built by the Greek. Under Arab rule, the city was already named Balad el-Fil or Medinat el-Fil, meaning “elephant's territory”. It is also said that the lava animal, dating back to the Roman era, belonged to a wizard and had the power to soothe the Etna. Which story do you believe in?

Fontana dell'Elefante
Piazza del Duomo, 14
95124 Catania

www.comune.catania.it

content.title: The very Baroque Via dei Crociferi

introduction.small: In Catania's city centre, this street is a real open-air gallery and it unveils a huge architectural heritage.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The very Baroque Via dei Crociferi

paragraphs.text:
Built in the 18th century, the Via dei Crociferi unravels some architectural unity, paced by holy places in which you will have to stop. Start your promenade under the arch connecting the buildings of the former Benedictine convent to reach the San Benedetto church, where you can gaze at the unique nave and its marble staircase. Carry on to la Chiesa dei Gesuiti while enjoying the peaceful atmosphere up to the cloister, said to be the work of Vaccarini, as the architect was a past master at rebuilding his city after the infamous earthquake. A few steps away, you will merely have to look up to revel in the San Giuliano façade and its beautiful gallery.
Walk south from the Piazza San Francesco, and stop at number 91 to gaze at the Villa Cerami and its gardens, former family home to the Rosso di Cerami. It has now become the University's Department of Law. On number 70, Caffetteria Villaroel's terrace will provide a welcome break, before resuming your quest for all the city's gems, as this paper chase is virtually endless.

Via dei Crociferi
95100 Catania

content.title: Teatro Massimo Bellini, a crowning tribute to the composer

introduction.small: Between a guided tour backstage and a dream night at the opera, the choice is yours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Teatro Massimo Bellini, a crowning tribute to the composer

paragraphs.text:
It was meant to be: designed by architect Carlo Sada and located in Catania's most authentic neighbourhood, the opera proudly took on the name of local composer Vincenzo Bellini. Inaugurated in 1890 with a performance of Norma, this ambitious music temple has capitalized on the high-quality level of the acoustics, all through the four floors adorned with beautiful golden boxes. It still shines today, thanks to a program that gives pride of place to the classics. This could be a perfect opportunity for you to dust off your most impressive outfit…
Guided tours also convey the location's beauty, from the marbles of the sumptuous lobby to the elegant galleries surrounding the main room. Look up and witness wondrous frescoes on the ceiling, painted by Ernesto Bellandi and detailing four scenes from Bellini's most famous operas. Whatever you gaze at is a work of magic.

Teatro Massimo Bellini
via Giuseppe Perrotta,12
95131 Catania

+39 095 730 6111

www.teatromassimobellini.it

content.title: Teatro Romano: Greco-Roman remains between water and skies

introduction.small: Located in the midst of the city, the Roman theatre bears the signs of history through the ages.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Teatro Romano: Greco-Roman remains between water and skies

paragraphs.text:
The contrast between the theatre - first built during the Ancient Greece era - and modern housing is absolutely amazing. The darkness of the stones used will also make an impression, as lava rock gives it an even more remarkable appearance.
White marble softens the colour tones of this impressive place that could gather up to 7,000 people, giving you an idea of how important it was for the community. Over time, the traces of its Greek origins have been buried under successive reconstructions. The remains you witness now therefore belong to the Roman period of 200 A.D. The Amenano River used to flow in its underground structure, which allowed then for spectacular staging, like small naval battles.
Today, a beautiful pond edges the stage, at the foot of the steps, bringing some poetry to a solemn site.

Teatro Romano
Via Vittorio Emanuele II, 266
95124 Catania

+39 (0)95 715 0508

content.title: Nuova Trattoria del Forestiero, a plateful of lyricism

introduction.small: Excellence and simplicity can lead to the creation of the greatest musical works. Inspired by this precept, the Nuova Trattoria del Forestiero cooks the best pasta alla Norma on the island.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nuova Trattoria del Forestiero, a plateful of lyricism

paragraphs.text:
A typical and savoury dish from Catania, the pasta alla Norma is composed of macaroni, fried aubergines, ricotta and fresh basil. It owes its name to local literary man Nino Martoglio, who tasted it and exclaimed "È una vera Norma!" ("It's a true Norma!") - referring to the title of Vincenzo Bellini's two-act opera, himself a native of Catania. Both the Sicilian composer's work and the pasta recipe have been critically acclaimed by the locals ever since, especially at the Nuova Trattoria del Forestiero.
Within the ochre walls of this quaint restaurant, you will catch a glimpse of the mamma (still running the kitchen in her seventies) who prepares the famous recipe. Her son manages table service singlehandedly, too, so a bit of patience is required. Let time take its course; you will be rewarded by a copious plateful, a divine pleasure from the very first bite!

Nuova Trattoria del Forestiero
Via Pietro Antonio Coppola, 26
95131 Catania

+39 095 316 283

Menu: around 12 EUR

content.title: Mè Cumpari Turiddu, an ode to eco-responsible gastronomy

introduction.small: A take-away snack, a delicate breakfast, or a refined dinner in the city centre: your call, the delicious menus of this place being all about “alternative consumption” practices.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mè Cumpari Turiddu, an ode to eco-responsible gastronomy

paragraphs.text:
Enter the world of Mè Cumpari Turiddu: an atypical place functioning as a grocery, pub and restaurant, with a huge kitchen taking centre stage. Feel welcome in this cordial Sicilian house with baroque chandeliers and tables dressed in white (for a dinner at the restaurant) or with lace (for a breakfast in the pub)…
The philosophy behind Mè Cumpari Turiddu is based on the guidelines of the "Slow Food" movement - which consists, mostly, in collaborating directly with small-scale local producers without any intermediary, and selecting only natural and organic products. This quality standard makes its way onto the plates: fresh fish, cold meats, Sicilian cheese, vegetables… Updated daily, the menu holds a culinary surprise for you, every day, under the benevolent gaze of the reserved yet considerate manageress of the place, Roberta.

Mè Cumpari Turiddu

content.title: “Il chiosco” or the picturesque charm of Catania

introduction.small: A refuge for the thirsty; a place to rally passersby; a 100%-Catanian recipe.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: “Il chiosco” or the picturesque charm of Catania

paragraphs.text:
Since 1896, chiosci Vezzosi and Giammona have kept watch over their piazze like venerable guardians of Catania's heritage. Decorated with foliage plants and light garlands, these lovely booths are genuine institutions that play the tradition card. Here, there is no newspaper or souvenir to be found; only homemade drinks based on fruit syrup, blended with sparkling water.
Locals gather there at any hour of the day or night to sip on drinks; most of all, the legendary Seltz limone e sale - a natural, particularly invigorating mix of low-iodine Seltz water and freshly squeezed lemon juice. Mandarin, Morello cherry, almond syrup, mint: dozens of scrumptious varieties end up in compositions whose secret fabrication is passed down from father to son.
Formerly open in spring and summertime only, now operative all year long, the booths welcome regular customers and casual visitors alike - as if they were small lighthouses scattered across the city. Salute!

content.title: Ostello degli Elefanti, a youth hostel unlike any other

introduction.small: Just a few steps away from the Piazza del Duomo, the Ostello degli Elefanti well deserves a short stay with friends.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ostello degli Elefanti, a youth hostel unlike any other

paragraphs.text:
Younger or older, in solo or duo, with family or friends: as long as there is vacancy, the Ostello degli Elefanti will fit everyone! With two, four, eight and up to ten beds - whether in a private double-room or in a dormitory version - the hostel is devoted to open-mindedness and hospitality.
This very unusual place has plenty of hidden treasures, such as a roof terrace offering an extraordinary view on the Etna, and ceilings entirely covered with 17th-century frescoes. As proof that youth hostels are not always synonymous with rusticity, here you will enjoy the neat design of spacious and welcoming rooms, as well as a restaurant open for lunch and dinner which offers typical menus, based on fresh and seasonal products.
If you add to that the huge advantage of rates being amongst the most affordable in Catania, then you have all the reasons in the world to stay a while at the Ostello degli Elefanti!

Ostello degli Elefanti

95124 Catania

content.title: The delicious Savia

introduction.small: Feeling the irresistible urge to take a break after a romantic stroll in Bellini Park? Treat yourself to some delicacies, courtesy of Savia.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The delicious Savia

paragraphs.text:
Since 1897, Savia has looked after savoury traditions not limited to sweet tooths. Culinary trends come and go; Savia remains an institution. Keeper of the flame of Catania's specialities - to eat in or take away - the pasticceria pleases both the locals and visiting friends. You really have to stop there in order to discover the city's best cannoli alla ricotta, as well as the traditional arancini al ragù or Saint Agatha's olivette; the brioche, granite and paste al pistacchio (made with almond and pistachio)…
As you can well imagine, behind Savia lies an authentic realm of temptation. Do not let the rush-hour queue scare you away: the longer the wait, the sweeter the treat…

content.title: Palazzu Stidda, for the love of art

introduction.small: An intimate location to get off the beaten track. Enter this secret and majestic nest for a moment of peace, and get connected with art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Palazzu Stidda, for the love of art

paragraphs.text:
Located between the cathedral and the Ursino castle, a stone's throw from the Pescheria, this private mansion ranks among the city's best kept secrets. This magnificent 19th-century abode overlooks one of the most charming alleys of Catania.
Palazzu Stidda offers four apartments - one with a breakfast area, the other three with kitchens - all decorated with taste and simplicity, emphasising the nobility of raw materials.
As you come inside, let the exquisite fragrances of aromatic plants lure you back out to the lemon trees planted on the terrace.
This is a personal, yet very welcoming space in which "memory verges on love and art", as current owners Patrizia and Giovanni like to point out. Palazzu Stidda also holds a gallery reflecting the passion that inhabits the two artists - who work with clay, bronze and stained glass in the wonderful arched workshops of the ground floor.

95021 Catania

content.title: Razmataz, the wine of the merry

introduction.small: Because aperitivo is a moment that you cannot miss if you want to taste real Italian culture, enjoy it at Razmataz, a wine bar acknowledged by many a gourmet.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Razmataz, the wine of the merry

paragraphs.text:
Looking for a cup of wine before the night starts? Locals will undoubtedly point you towards "Razmataz". Located on Via Montesano Centrale, and mere steps away from Via Etnea, this authentic wine bar comes with a promise of homely happiness: the tasting of cellar treasures surrounded by woodwork of years gone by.
On particularly hot days, it is impossible to resist the calling of the lovely tables on the terrace, enjoying the shadow of the tree that adds up to the old-fashioned charm of the place. Should you wish to prolong the pleasure, Razmataz also has a menu with typical dishes of Sicily (pasta with fresh salmon and broccoli, meatballs in bittersweet ginger sauce…) and offers vegetarian food on a daily basis - so anyone can appreciate moments of this gentle lifestyle, so dear to the people of Catania.

Razmataz

95131 Catania

content.title: FUD: where fashion and tradition meet

introduction.small: Soft bread rolls, Sicilian meat, homemade side dishes… Trendy? Obviously. Delicious? First and foremost. Have a taste of “made-in-Catania” burgers!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: FUD: where fashion and tradition meet

paragraphs.text:
"FUD" for thought? Surely you caught on the pun of this innovating concept: a menu that plays on Italian phonetics and mixes your usual fast-food standards with local dishes. The menu offers the "Am Burgher", a round bread roll served with Sicilian beef, tomatoes, salad and extra virgin olive oil; a pear, gorgonzola and nuts salad; or even the “Cicchen Oddog”, with a chicken sausage rolled in soft bread, bacon and curry sauce.
As witty, practical and trendy as you can expect from its interior decoration, FUD should not be reduced to clever plays on words: dishes are made in front of you, and on the spot, at the counter. If you are not already convinced, note that sharing plates are available, with lunch meats and Sicilian cheese, Nebrodi black pork or goat cheese. FUD is "food" spelled with capital F, U, and D!

content.title: Discover Catania's Cathedral

introduction.small: Catania's most impressive building stands proud on the Piazza del Duomo. Today a consecrated cathedral, it used to be a fortress-church against Saracen invasions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover Catania's Cathedral

paragraphs.text:
The sumptuous Baroque façade of the Sant'Agata Cathedral is the work of Sicilian architect Vaccarini. It majestically overlooks the elephant of the famous Fontana dell'Elefante in front.
Observe the Aragonese sovereigns' coat of arms on the sublime solid wood doorway. Also of interest is the story of Saint Agathe, a young virgin martyr who gave her name to the cathedral and whose relics have been preserved on the premises. One of the chapels houses the tomb of Vincenzo Bellini and the sarcophaguses of three Aragonese kings.
Built towards the end of the 11th century by order of Normand Roger I where former Roman baths stood, the structure had to be almost entirely reconstructed after the terrible 1693 earthquake. Only the two towers and the transept withstood the shock. On one side of the façade, you can make out the lava stone semi-circular apses. Collect your thoughts or simply let go of everything while the piece that reigns inside wins you over.

Basilica Cattedrale Sant'Agata
Via Vittorio Emanuele II, 163
95131 Catania

+39 095 320 044

www.cattedralecatania.it

content.title: Discover the most beautiful beaches in Sicily

introduction.small: With about 1,500 kilometres of coastline, Sicily unravels a paradise of crystal blue waters. To relax and enjoy, everyone go to la spiaggia!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover the most beautiful beaches in Sicily

paragraphs.text:
If the island carries a fire within, it also offers an exceptional coastline. Spread out and varied, from crescent-shape fine sand to shingle coves, beaches draw another picture of Sicily.
As a strange horizon of black lava rock, San Giovanni li Cuti remains Catania's most famous beach. However, you only have to head towards Noto – a Baroque gem – to find many other idyllic landscapes… Filled with parasols in high season, Eloro and Calamosche are among those golden sandy Eldorados very much sought after, and therefore rapidly crowded.
If you crave some intimacy, head to the Spiaggia Gelsomineto, considered to be the most beautiful beach of the entire island. This hidden paradise, near the Cassibile River and nestled between Avola and Syracuse, is surrounded with stone pines, holm oaks and reeds. There, cicadas are the only ones breaking the silence…

Spiaggia di Eloro
96017 Noto

Spiaggia Calamosche
96017 Noto

Spiaggia Gelsomineto
96012 Avola

content.title: Family outing in the Alcantara gorge

introduction.small: During your stay in Sicily, you will have many occasions to relax to nature. Start by discovering the incredible landscape provided by the Alcantara gorges.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Family outing in the Alcantara gorge

paragraphs.text:
The small Sicilian Alcantara River, between the Etna in the south and the Nebrodi and Peloritani peaks in the north, flows directly into the Ionian Sea. Volcanic activities in the region have shaped the impressive Alcantara gorges, where curiously-shaped rock formations and unexpected landscapes are aplenty. The 10-metre high narrow basalt columns will dazzle you.
For adventurers, there are canyoning possibilities with a network of streams, rock and waterfalls. You can also swim in some sections of the Alcantara, or simply let the river carry you. Revel in the spectacle of incredible crystal-clear waters, ubiquitous oleanders on the riversides and orange groves everywhere. Beware though, the water may be a little cold!

www.parcoalcantara.it/Findex.php

content.title: Palazzo Biscari, palace of Sicilian taste for excess

introduction.small: The Palazzo Biscari is an aristocratic house with Baroque decoration of extreme refinement. It is Catania's pride and joy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Palazzo Biscari, palace of Sicilian taste for excess

paragraphs.text:
Here is one of Catania's most wondrous palaces, erected on the city's former Spanish fortifications. Its massive figure spreads from Via Vittorio Emanuele II to Via Dusmet. The sculpted elements are interspersed with window frames and announce the ostentatious nature inside.
Alternately house of the Paterno Castello family and Biscari princes, it has come forward as the symbol of the brutal shift from the Renaissance style. After the 1693 earthquake, Ignazio Biscari, famed lover of the arts, imagines a new style and decoration for the place. With gildings, frescoes and ornaments, gorgeous painted ceilings, music rooms and scrolled staircase railings, the various areas took on sophisticated pomp, intensifying its creator's will for uniqueness. This capricious geometry brings constant ravishment to visitors, one of them none other than Goethe, who described its abundance of luxury and extravagance in his writings. Note that visits need be booked beforehand.

Palazzo Biscari
Via Museo Biscari 10-16
95131 Catania

+39 095 715 2508

www.palazzobiscari.it/

content.title: Villa Bellini's delightful tropical garden

introduction.small: Offering both amazing botanical heritage and buried history, the Bellini gardens are among the most beautiful throughout Europe.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Villa Bellini's delightful tropical garden

paragraphs.text:
In the 18th century, the Villa Bellini was owned by prince Ignazio Paterno Castello di Biscari, who transformed the bordering park into a green maze, punctuated with fountains, water games and statues. The building having become the property of the city of Catania, architects Ignazio Landolina and Filadelfo Fichera enlarged the green spaces and created this fabulous and intricate ensemble, between lushness and eccentricity.
Swallowed up by various subtropical tree varieties, including the extremely rare Ficus Macrophylia, sets of stairs, bridges and walking alleys play hide and seek as faint music can be heard from the gazebo. Here and there, you will see statues and bust in cast iron, bronze and marble - Vincenzo Bellini's is obviously one of them - as the central fountain offers a refreshing resting point. Do not hesitate to get off the beaten track, you won't regret it!

Bellini Gardens
Via Etnea, 292
95131 Catania

+39 095 320 761

www.comune.catania.it

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Catania
content.introduction: Catania enjoys a typically Mediterranean climate. Summers are hot and dry, although sea breezes help to cool down the city. Winters are mild and humid. January and February are the coldest months. For trek and adventure lovers, the weather during Spring and Autumn is ideal.

airports.title: Catania-Fontanarossa International Airport
airports.description:
The Catania-Fontanarossa International Airport is located about 6 kilometres (4 miles) north-east of the city centre.
  • One terminal:
    • Terminal A (Air France)

Getting from the airport to Catania and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via the A19 highway (coming from the west) and the A18 highway (following the coastline from the north), as well as express road E45 (coastline from the south).
    • There are two short-term parking facilities - P1 and P2 - located about 40 and 200 metres respectively from Terminal A (free for 15 minutes, then EUR 2 from 16 minutes to 1 hour) and one long-term facility (P4) located about 200 metres from Terminal A (EUR 17 for the first 48 hours).
    • Several car rental companies have counters at the arrivals hall in the airport.
  • By bus
    • "Alibus" AMT buses connect Catania's central station to the airport every 25 minutes, from 5 a.m. to midnight. Tickets (about EUR 4 to reach the city centre) are available at the ticket office in front of the bus stop.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available at the ranks just outside the terminals. Expect a EUR 25 fare to the centre of Catania and a 15 to 30-minute trip, depending on traffic.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +39 (0)95 723 9111
  • Website: www.aeroporto.catania.it/?lang=en

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Catania
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Catania each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: January 6: Epiphany (Feast of Befana, national)
events.description: For all Italians, the 6<sup>th</sup> of January is the day when the benevolent white witch Befana, who predates Santa Claus in Italy, arrives on her broomstick with presents and candy for all children who have been good during the year or a lump of coal if they have been bad!

events.title: February 3-5: Feast of Sant'Agatha (local)
events.description: For a few days around February 5, the city celebrates Sant'Agatha, virgin and martyr, with a torchlight parade called luminaria. An impressive procession (the crowd sometimes reaches up to a million individuals) arrives at the San Biagio Church, where the saint was burnt for refusing to marry the Quinzino proconsul, prefect of Sicily.

events.title: One week before Easter: Holy Week (national)
events.description: Solemn processions and passion plays in the streets mark the week leading up to Easter in Catania.

events.title: May 1: Labour Day (national)
events.description: Artistic associations organise events in the historic centre of the city: performances, workshops, street theatre, and more.

events.title: June 2: Republic Day - Festa della Repubblica -  (national)
events.description: To commemorate the birth of the Italian Republic in 1946, celebrations, fireworks displays, parades and street dances are held all over Catania and other Italian cities.

events.title: August 15: Ferragosto (national)
events.description: This holiday is dedicated to the celebration of the Virgin Mary. Mass and several processions take place in the churches and streets of the historic centre to honour her.

events.title: November 1: All Saints Day (national)
events.description: All Saints Day is a holiday in Italy. It is the celebration day of all Saints, with numerous events organised all around town.

events.title: November 4: National Unity and Armed Forces Day (national)
events.description: For this official commemoration of Italian reunification and the end of the First World War, military parades are held across the city.

events.title: December 26: Santo Stefano (national)
events.description: Celebrates the birth of Santo Stefano. Traditionally, Italians sit down to a large and festive meal with their families.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Italy
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you do not need to obtain a visa if you will be staying in Italy for less than three months. If you plan to stay for more than 90 days, you will need to obtain a long-stay visa.
To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Catania and Italy, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations. Comprehensive information that may be helpful for international visitors is also provided on the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs’ website. View information for travellers to Italy:

http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/conseils-par-pays/italie

goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
Tipping is often included in the bill, under the header “servizio” (service). However, you can leave a tip if you've been pleased with the service. In the bill, you will sometimes find the header “pane e coperto” (bread and cutlery) which corresponds to bread and setting. Make sure the price includes tip and setting.
